info.name: Into the Castle
info.attribution:
Board layout by Shobu and ArnoldSmith86. Released to public domain under CC0.

The background image (and library image) were generated by Midjourney using the prompt "map of a classic rpg game: lush forest with a big cathedral (see-thru roof) in the center, pixelart --ar 16:10" and edited by Shobu.

The sword icon is by Lorc and used under the CC BY 3.0 license: https://game-icons.net/1x1/lorc/sword-spin.html
info.description: Roll dice and send your meeples out to fight for coins.
info.ruleText:
OVERVIEW
There are 6 levels of the castle, each corresponding to a face on the dice. The highest level has gold coins (worth many points). Each player starts with 12 meeples in their player color.

You will roll dice, arrange them in sequence, and place meeples to fight for control of areas (numbers at the bottom) and gain those area's coins at the end of the game.

TURN STRUCTURE
On your turn, use the gray sword button to roll all the dice in the box at the top. You can reroll as many dice as you like each time, but only 3 total rolls are allowed. Place any dice you do not want to reroll outside the top gray box. Once you decide to stop rolling, arrange your dice in numerical order, with the gold above the 5 face.
  • If you have rolled no dice faces with the number 1, your turn ends.
  • If you have a perfect sequence (1-2-3-4-5-gold), take a gold coin from the top of the castle and secretly place into your "Won Gold" area. You have earned a bonus - so take an additional turn!
  • In all other cases, choose a number from the unbroken start of your sequence. Once the sequence is interrupted, you cannot choose the higher numbers. For that chosen number, place meeple(s) matching the number of dice you rolled with that face onto the board next to that dice face's number.
    • Example 1: if your final sequence is 1-2-4-5, you may choose either 1 or 2.
    • Example 2: if you rolled a 1 and three 2s, you could place either a single meeple on the 1 board space or 3 meeples on the 2 space on the board. If you don't have enough meeples, just place all your remaining meeples on that number.
GAME END
The game ends when either:
  1. A player takes the last gold coin - the game stops immediately.
  2. A player places their last meeple. In this case, all other players get 1 final turn before the game stops.
TAKE GRAY COINS
Each number on the board, starting with 5 and going down, is resolved and its coins distributed as described below.
  • The player with the most meeples in a level gets the highest (Left side) coin for that level.
  • The player with the second most meeples on that level gets a coin from the Right side.
  • In 4-player games, the player with the third most meeples gets the other Right side coin for that level.
  • If a player has no meeples on a level, they get none of that level's coins.
TIES
  • If players have the same number of meeples for a level, the tied player with the most meeples on the level below that one will win the tie and get the coin.
  • If still tied, check each lower level.
  • If they have the same number of meeples all the way to level 1, whoever has more unused meeples in their supply wins the tie.
  • If still tied, whoever took their last turn earlier wins the tie.
SCORING
The player with the most points (summed from the numbers on the coins they acquired) is the winner.

fields.text: Are you sure you want to reset the game?

clickRoutine.Note: Clicking the button starts the timer.

millisecondsChangeRoutine.Note: If the button is paused, then do nothing.

elseRoutine.Note: If the timer is not paused, then get all the variables need for the timer to perform its functions.

elseRoutine: // These try to space the dice evenly across the Dice Container

loopRoutine.Note: Die is given a random number of times to land for each roll if not already set.
If the number of remaining rolls is 1 or more, keep rolling.

elseRoutine.Note: If no rolls remain, set the scale back to 1.

elseRoutine: // Extra roll to allow the animations to finish.

elseRoutine.Note: If the number of rolls done is greater than or equal to the max number of rolls of any die, we're done. Do some cleanup.

thenRoutine.Note: If no rolls remain, set the scale back to 1.
